awd_titl_txt: Coherent Control of Single Neodymium Ion Qubits
awd_abstract_narration:
Controlling the properties of single atoms at the quantum mechanical level promises to enable revolutionary quantum technologies with application in computing, secure communication and precision measurements. From the prospect of developing a scalable technology, it is very appealing to work with atoms trapped in solids. Rare-earth atoms in crystals are a very promising system to study because their quantum properties are not significantly degraded by the interaction with the other atoms in the solid. This project will be focused on controlling the quantum states of single neodymium atoms using optical laser pulses and microwave pulses. These studies will determine whether neodymium atoms are well suited for developing quantum technologies, especially quantum communications. This project will allow for training the future generation of scientists and engineers with expertise in quantum science and technology.

Studying and controlling single quantum bits in solids is at the current frontier of quantum information science. To advance this frontier, optical spectroscopy and spin control of single neodymium ions coupled to nano-photonic resonators will be performed, and the prospects for using them as reliable quantum bits will be assessed. The reason for using rare-earth-ions, specifically neodymium, is that they have 4f electronic levels exhibiting some of the best optical and spin quantum coherence in the solid state, similar to trapped atoms and ions.  This study will lead to a better understanding of the interactions between single ions and their nano-scale environment, such as nearby surfaces, hyperfine coupling between nuclei, and ion-ion dipole interaction that have not been studied before at the single quantum level. New optical techniques combining high-frequency-resolution laser spectroscopy, nano-photonics, low temperature, microwave spin control will be developed. Nano-fabrication techniques for new crystalline materials will be further advanced.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to demonstrate coherent control, via optical and microwave fields, of the quantum states of single rare-earth ions (REIs) embedded in photonic crystal resonators. This will enable optically addressable quantum bits based on REIs that may lead to future optical quantum networks. The reason for using REIs is that they have 4f electronic levels exhibiting some of the best optical and spin quantum coherence in solid-state, similar to trapped atoms and ions. The excellent coherence and spectral stability are preserved while coupled to nano-devices, because the 4f levels are well shielded from interactions with the environment. However, good shielding and long optical coherence are correlated with weak luminescence, so coupling to nano-cavities is essential. The first objective was to initialize and readout the single ion electron spin of a single REI using radio frequency and laser pulses. The second objective was to demonstrate coherent optical control of the electron spin qubit.

 

Both objectives have been accomplished using ytterbium 171 REI in yttrium orthovanadate, that was deemed more suitable than neodymium for future optical quantum networks because of the long spin coherence enabled by clock transitions. In addition to these objectives we demonstrated that the ytterbium 171 qubit couples to nearby vanadium nuclear spins that can be used as a local quantum memory register, an essential functionality for future quantum repeater networks.

 Intellectual Merit: Studying and controlling single quantum bits in solids is at the current frontier of quantum information science. To advance this frontier, optical spectroscopy and spin control of single REIs was performed and the prospects for using them as reliable quantum bits was assessed. This will result in better understanding of the interactions between single ions and their nano-scale environment, such as nearby surfaces, hyperfine coupling between nuclei and ion-ion dipole interaction that have not been studied before at single quantum level. New optical techniques combining high-frequency-resolution laser spectroscopy, nano-photonics, low temperature, radio frequency spin control were be developed.

Broader Impact: Quantum devices promise to drive the next technological revolution. They will give us the capability to solve certain problems in a short time, such as protein folding for drug discovery and quantum simulation of new materials. They will also enable the capability to communicate with absolute security in our highly interconnected society. This project provided opportunities to train graduate students in developing quantum technologies. It required the students to understand and employ solid-state physics, optical engineering, and nano-fabrication techniques. The students also developed a complex measurement setup. In addition to graduate student education, undergraduate students contributed to the project through the summer undergraduate research fellowship program at Caltech.
